block.p: Moira Ann Crouch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Woodrow Crouch of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Brian James Bandsma, a son of Mary Bandsma of Shawano, Wis., and Robert Bandsma of Coloma, Wis. The Rev. Francis Gorman performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary.

Ms. Crouch, 31, is keeping her name. She is an associate at Masur & Associates, a law firm in Manhattan. She graduated from Connecticut College and received her law degree from George Washington University. She is also a member of the board of the New York Pro Arte Chamber Orchestra. Her father works in White Plains as the vice president for project management of the New York Power Authority. Her mother, Mary Crouch, teaches English as a second language at public schools in the Bronx.

Moira Ann Crouch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Woodrow Crouch of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Brian James Bandsma, a son of Mary Bandsma of Shawano, Wis., and Robert Bandsma of Coloma, Wis. The Rev. Francis Gorman performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary.

Ms. Crouch, 31, is keeping her name. She is an associate at Masur & Associates, a law firm in Manhattan. She graduated from Connecticut College and received her law degree from George Washington University. She is also a member of the board of the New York Pro Arte Chamber Orchestra. Her father works in White Plains as the vice president for project management of the New York Power Authority. Her mother, Mary Crouch, teaches English as a second language at public schools in the Bronx.

Mr. Bandsma, 28, is a senior associate and financial adviser at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, an investment management firm in New York. He graduated cum laude from Grand Valley State University. His mother is a laboratory technician at Shawano County Hospital. His father owns Ecowater, a company in Coloma that makes and installs water filtering systems in homes and businesses.
